segment.source: Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0 stores its configuration settings in the registry.
segment.target: Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0 stores its configuration settings in the registry.

segment.source: The information we include here about the registry may help you better manage your MED-V services.
segment.target: The information we include here about the registry may help you better manage your MED-V services.

segment.source: MED-V uses the following search path when looking for the resultant settings values:
segment.target: MED-V uses the following search path when looking for the resultant settings values:

segment.source: MED-V first looks in the machine policy.
segment.target: MED-V first looks in the machine policy.

segment.source: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the user policy.
segment.target: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the user policy.

segment.source: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESystem hive.
segment.target: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESystem hive.

segment.source: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the HKEYCURRENT USER registry hive.
segment.target: If the value is not found, MED-V looks in the HKEYCURRENT USER registry hive.

segment.source: If the value is still not found, MED-V uses the default.
segment.target: If the value is still not found, MED-V uses the default.

segment.source: A general best practice is to set the value in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESystem hive or in the machine policy.
segment.target: A general best practice is to set the value in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESystem hive or in the machine policy.

segment.source: But if you want the end user to be able to configure a particular setting, then you should leave it out.
segment.target: But if you want the end user to be able to configure a particular setting, then you should leave it out.

segment.source: Before you deploy your MED-V workspaces, you can use a script editor to change the Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 file) that the MED-V workspace packager created.
segment.target: Before you deploy your MED-V workspaces, you can use a script editor to change the Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 file) that the MED-V workspace packager created.

segment.source: For more information, see Configuring Advanced Settings by Using Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: For more information, see Configuring Advanced Settings by Using Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: After you have deployed your MED-V workspaces, you can change certain MED-V configuration settings by editing the registry entries.
segment.target: After you have deployed your MED-V workspaces, you can change certain MED-V configuration settings by editing the registry entries.

segment.source: This section lists all the configurable MED-V registry keys and explains their uses.
segment.target: This section lists all the configurable MED-V registry keys and explains their uses.

segment.source: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2Diagnostics key.
segment.target: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2Diagnostics key.

segment.source: The type of information that is logged in the event log.
segment.target: The type of information that is logged in the event log.

segment.source: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2Fts key.
segment.target: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2Fts key.

segment.source: Configures whether first time setup automatically adds the end user to the administrator's group.
segment.target: Configures whether first time setup automatically adds the end user to the administrator's group.

segment.source: 0 = false: First time setup does not automatically add the end user to the administrator's group.
segment.target: 0 = false: First time setup does not automatically add the end user to the administrator's group.

segment.source: 1 = true: First time setup automatically adds the end user to the administrator's group.
segment.target: 1 = true: First time setup automatically adds the end user to the administrator's group.

segment.source: The computer name mask that is used to create the guest virtual machine's computer name.
segment.target: The computer name mask that is used to create the guest virtual machine's computer name.

segment.source: The mask can contain a %username% tag to insert the username as part of the computer name.
segment.target: The mask can contain a %username% tag to insert the username as part of the computer name.

segment.source: Likewise, the %hostname% tag inserts the name of the host computer.
segment.target: Likewise, the %hostname% tag inserts the name of the host computer.

segment.source: Every character in the mask is replaced by a random digit.
segment.target: Every character in the mask is replaced by a random digit.

segment.source: An asterisk (*) character at the end of the mask is replaced by random alphanumeric characters.
segment.target: An asterisk (*) character at the end of the mask is replaced by random alphanumeric characters.

segment.source: A specific number of characters from %hostname% and %username% can be captured by using square brackets.
segment.target: A specific number of characters from %hostname% and %username% can be captured by using square brackets.

segment.source: For example, %username%[3] would use the first three characters of the username.
segment.target: For example, %username%[3] would use the first three characters of the username.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, when first time setup tries to delete the virtual machine.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, when first time setup tries to delete the virtual machine.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, when first time setup tries to detach the virtual floppy disk from the virtual machine.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, when first time setup tries to detach the virtual floppy disk from the virtual machine.

segment.source: Customizable URL that links to internal webpage and is displayed by first time setup dialog messages.
segment.target: Customizable URL that links to internal webpage and is displayed by first time setup dialog messages.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for Windows Explorer.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for Windows Explorer.

segment.source: Message is found in resource file
segment.target: Message is found in resource file

segment.source: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup cannot be completed.
segment.target: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup cannot be completed.

segment.source: The maximum number of times that MED-V tries to give an end user group rights.
segment.target: The maximum number of times that MED-V tries to give an end user group rights.

segment.source: Exceeding the specified retry value without being able to successfully give an end user group rights most likely causes a virtual machine preparation failure that is then subject to the MaxRetryCount value.
segment.target: Exceeding the specified retry value without being able to successfully give an end user group rights most likely causes a virtual machine preparation failure that is then subject to the MaxRetryCount value.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, when giving a user group rights.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, when giving a user group rights.

segment.source: A list of the log file paths that MED-V collects during first time setup.
segment.target: A list of the log file paths that MED-V collects during first time setup.

segment.source: The maximum number of hours that first time setup can be postponed by the end user.
segment.target: The maximum number of hours that first time setup can be postponed by the end user.

segment.source: The maximum number of times that MED-V tries to prepare a virtual machine if each attempt ends in a failure other than a software error.
segment.target: The maximum number of times that MED-V tries to prepare a virtual machine if each attempt ends in a failure other than a software error.

segment.source: When virtual machine preparation fails and the number of first time setup retries is exceeded, then MED-V informs the end user about the failure and does not give the option to retry.
segment.target: When virtual machine preparation fails and the number of first time setup retries is exceeded, then MED-V informs the end user about the failure and does not give the option to retry.

segment.source: The count is re-set every time that MED-V is started.
segment.target: The count is re-set every time that MED-V is started.

segment.source: Configures how first time setup interacts with the user.
segment.target: Configures how first time setup interacts with the user.

segment.source: The end user must enter information during first time setup.
segment.target: The end user must enter information during first time setup.

segment.source: If you created the Sysprep.inf file so that Mini-Setup requires user input to complete, then you must select Attended mode or problems might occur during first time setup.
segment.target: If you created the Sysprep.inf file so that Mini-Setup requires user input to complete, then you must select Attended mode or problems might occur during first time setup.

segment.source: The virtual machine is not shown to the end user during first time setup, but the end user is prompted before first time setup starts.
segment.target: The virtual machine is not shown to the end user during first time setup, but the end user is prompted before first time setup starts.

segment.source: The virtual machine is not shown to the end user at all during first time setup.
segment.target: The virtual machine is not shown to the end user at all during first time setup.

segment.source: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup must be completed in first time setup interactive mode when re-attempting setup.
segment.target: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup must be completed in first time setup interactive mode when re-attempting setup.

segment.source: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup must be completed in first time setup interactive mode.
segment.target: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup must be completed in first time setup interactive mode.

segment.source: The date and time, in UTC DateTime format, that first time setup can be postponed.
segment.target: The date and time, in UTC DateTime format, that first time setup can be postponed.

segment.source: Enter in the format yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm with hours specified by using the 24-hour clock standard.
segment.target: Enter in the format yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm with hours specified by using the 24-hour clock standard.

segment.source: Message is found in resource file
segment.target: Message is found in resource file

segment.source: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup must re-attempt setup.
segment.target: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup must re-attempt setup.

segment.source: Configures whether the ComputerName entry under the [UserData] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest should be updated according to the specified ComputerNameMask.
segment.target: Configures whether the ComputerName entry under the [UserData] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest should be updated according to the specified ComputerNameMask.

segment.source: 0 = false: The ComputerName entry in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated according to the ComputerNameMask.
segment.target: 0 = false: The ComputerName entry in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated according to the ComputerNameMask.

segment.source: 1 = true: The ComputerName entry in the Sysprep.inf file is updated according to the ComputerNameMask.
segment.target: 1 = true: The ComputerName entry in the Sysprep.inf file is updated according to the ComputerNameMask.

segment.source: Configures whether the JoinDomain setting under the [Identification] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest should be updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: Configures whether the JoinDomain setting under the [Identification] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest should be updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: 0 = false: The JoinDomain setting in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: The JoinDomain setting in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: The JoinDomain setting in the Sysprep.inf file is updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: The JoinDomain setting in the Sysprep.inf file is updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the MachineObjectOU setting under the [Identification] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest is updated to match the host.
segment.target: Configures whether the MachineObjectOU setting under the [Identification] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest is updated to match the host.

segment.source: 0 = false: The MachineObjectOU setting in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: The MachineObjectOU setting in the Sysprep.inf file is not updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: The MachineObjectOU setting in the Sysprep.inf file is updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: The MachineObjectOU setting in the Sysprep.inf file is updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the host.
segment.target: Configures whether the settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the host.

segment.source: By default, the setting for TimeZone in the guest is always synchronized with the TimeZone setting in the host.
segment.target: By default, the setting for TimeZone in the guest is always synchronized with the TimeZone setting in the host.

segment.source: 0 = false: The settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are not updated to match the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: The settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are not updated to match the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: The settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: The settings under the [RegionalSettings] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the FullName and the OrgName settings under the [UserData] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: Configures whether the FullName and the OrgName settings under the [UserData] section of the Sysprep.inf file in the guest are updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: 0 = false: The FullName and OrgName settings in the Sysprep.inf file are not updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: The FullName and OrgName settings in the Sysprep.inf file are not updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: The FullName and OrgName settings in the Sysprep.inf file are updated to match the settings on the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: The FullName and OrgName settings in the Sysprep.inf file are updated to match the settings on the host.

segment.source: Message is found in resource file
segment.target: Message is found in resource file

segment.source: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup is ready to start.
segment.target: Customizable message that is displayed to the end user when first time setup is ready to start.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for a response from the virtual machine for a Cancel operation.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for a response from the virtual machine for a Cancel operation.

segment.source: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for the virtual machine to shut down.
segment.target: The time-out value, in seconds, that first time setup waits for the virtual machine to shut down.

segment.source: The time, in seconds, before an attempted upgrade of the MED-V Guest Agent software times out.
segment.target: The time, in seconds, before an attempted upgrade of the MED-V Guest Agent software times out.

segment.source: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2UserExperience key and the HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftMedvv2UserExperience key.
segment.target: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2UserExperience key and the HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftMedvv2UserExperience key.

segment.source: Configures whether application publication from the guest to the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether application publication from the guest to the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables application publishing from the guest to the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables application publishing from the guest to the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables application publishing from the guest to the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables application publishing from the guest to the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of the audio I/O device between the guest and the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of the Clipboard between the guest and the host.

segment.source: The time, in seconds, before the first time setup Start Dialog times out.
segment.target: The time, in seconds, before the first time setup Start Dialog times out.

segment.source: The time-out value, in minutes, that the full-screen virtual machine window is hidden from the end user during a long logon attempt.
segment.target: The time-out value, in minutes, that the full-screen virtual machine window is hidden from the end user during a long logon attempt.

segment.source: Configures whether the guest should be started when the end user logs on to the desktop or when the first guest application is started.
segment.target: Configures whether the guest should be started when the end user logs on to the desktop or when the first guest application is started.

segment.source: 0 = false: The guest is started when the first guest application is started.
segment.target: 0 = false: The guest is started when the first guest application is started.

segment.source: 1 = true: The guest is started when the end user logs on to the desktop.
segment.target: 1 = true: The guest is started when the end user logs on to the desktop.

segment.source: Configures whether the sharing of printers between the guest and the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether the sharing of printers between the guest and the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of printers between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of printers between the guest and the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of printers between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of printers between the guest and the host.

segment.source: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup waits for a restart.
segment.target: The time-out value, in minutes, that first time setup waits for a restart.

segment.source: Specifies a list of URLs to be redirected from the host to the guest.
segment.target: Specifies a list of URLs to be redirected from the host to the guest.

segment.source: Configures whether smart cards can be used to authenticate users to MED-V.
segment.target: Configures whether smart cards can be used to authenticate users to MED-V.

segment.source: 0 = false: Does not let Smart Cards authenticate end users to MED-V.
segment.target: 0 = false: Does not let Smart Cards authenticate end users to MED-V.

segment.source: 1 = true: Lets Smart Cards authenticate end users to MED-V.
segment.target: 1 = true: Lets Smart Cards authenticate end users to MED-V.

segment.source: If SmartCardLogonEnabled and CredentialCacheEnabled are both enabled, SmartCardLogonEnabled overrides CredentialCacheEnabled.
segment.target: If SmartCardLogonEnabled and CredentialCacheEnabled are both enabled, SmartCardLogonEnabled overrides CredentialCacheEnabled.

segment.source: Configures whether the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of Smart Cards between the guest and the host.

segment.source: Configures whether the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host is enabled.
segment.target: Configures whether the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host is enabled.

segment.source: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: Disables the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: Enables the sharing of USB devices between the guest and the host.

segment.source: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2VM key and the HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftMedvv2VM key.
segment.target: The following table provides information about the registry values associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2VM key and the HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftMedvv2VM key.

segment.source: The action that the virtual machine performs after the last application that is running is closed.
segment.target: The action that the virtual machine performs after the last application that is running is closed.

segment.source: This setting is ignored if the LogonStartEnabled value is enabled.
segment.target: This setting is ignored if the LogonStartEnabled value is enabled.

segment.source: This option releases all physical resources that the virtual machine is using, such as memory and CPU, and saves the state of all running applications and operations.
segment.target: This option releases all physical resources that the virtual machine is using, such as memory and CPU, and saves the state of all running applications and operations.

segment.source: This option shuts down the guest operating system safely and then releases all physical resources that the virtual machine is using, such as memory and CPU.
segment.target: This option shuts down the guest operating system safely and then releases all physical resources that the virtual machine is using, such as memory and CPU.

segment.source: This option can cause data loss because it is the same as turning off the power button or pulling out the power cord on a physical computer.
segment.target: This option can cause data loss because it is the same as turning off the power button or pulling out the power cord on a physical computer.

segment.source: Use this option only if you cannot use one of the other two options.
segment.target: Use this option only if you cannot use one of the other two options.

segment.source: A list of memory (MB) values for the guest.
segment.target: A list of memory (MB) values for the guest.

segment.source: This value is used to determine how much RAM is available to the guest.
segment.target: This value is used to determine how much RAM is available to the guest.

segment.source: Combined with HostMemToGuestMem, a lookup table is created to determine how much RAM to allocate on the guest virtual machine.
segment.target: Combined with HostMemToGuestMem, a lookup table is created to determine how much RAM to allocate on the guest virtual machine.

segment.source: Possible values can be from 128 to 3712.
segment.target: Possible values can be from 128 to 3712.

segment.source: The number of minutes that MED-V should keep the guest awake for automatic updating, starting at the time specified in the GuestUpdateTime value.
segment.target: The number of minutes that MED-V should keep the guest awake for automatic updating, starting at the time specified in the GuestUpdateTime value.

segment.source: Setting this value to zero (0) disables the guest patching functionality.
segment.target: Setting this value to zero (0) disables the guest patching functionality.

segment.source: For more information about guest patching for automatic updating, see Managing Automatic Updates for MED-V Workspaces.
segment.target: For more information about guest patching for automatic updating, see Managing Automatic Updates for MED-V Workspaces.

segment.source: The hour and minute each day when MED-V should wake up the guest for automatic updating, by using the 24-hour clock standard.
segment.target: The hour and minute each day when MED-V should wake up the guest for automatic updating, by using the 24-hour clock standard.

segment.source: Specify the time in the format HH:MM
segment.target: Specify the time in the format HH:MM

segment.source: For more information about guest patching for automatic updating, see Managing Automatic Updates for MED-V Workspaces.
segment.target: For more information about guest patching for automatic updating, see Managing Automatic Updates for MED-V Workspaces.

segment.source: A list of memory (MB) values for the guest, determined by the RAM available on the host.
segment.target: A list of memory (MB) values for the guest, determined by the RAM available on the host.

segment.source: Combined with GuestMemFromHostMem, a lookup table is created to determine how much RAM to allocate on the guest virtual machine.
segment.target: Combined with GuestMemFromHostMem, a lookup table is created to determine how much RAM to allocate on the guest virtual machine.

segment.source: Possible values can be from 1024 to 16384.
segment.target: Possible values can be from 1024 to 16384.

segment.source: Configures whether the memory allocated for the guest is calculated from the memory present on the host.
segment.target: Configures whether the memory allocated for the guest is calculated from the memory present on the host.

segment.source: 0 = false: The memory allocated for the guest is not calculated from the memory present on the host.
segment.target: 0 = false: The memory allocated for the guest is not calculated from the memory present on the host.

segment.source: 1 = true: The memory allocated for the guest is calculated from the memory present on the host.
segment.target: 1 = true: The memory allocated for the guest is calculated from the memory present on the host.

segment.source: The RAM (MB) that should be allocated for the guest virtual machine.
segment.target: The RAM (MB) that should be allocated for the guest virtual machine.

segment.source: This setting is ignored if the HostMemToGuestMemEnabled setting is enabled.
segment.target: This setting is ignored if the HostMemToGuestMemEnabled setting is enabled.

segment.source: Configures whether multiple users share the same MED-V workspace.
segment.target: Configures whether multiple users share the same MED-V workspace.

segment.source: 0 = false: Multiple users do not share the same MED-V workspace.
segment.target: 0 = false: Multiple users do not share the same MED-V workspace.

segment.source: 1 = true: Multiple users share the same MED-V workspace.
segment.target: 1 = true: Multiple users share the same MED-V workspace.

segment.source: The kind of network connection used on the guest.
segment.target: The kind of network connection used on the guest.

segment.source: MED-V has its own network address, typically obtained through DHCP.
segment.target: MED-V has its own network address, typically obtained through DHCP.

segment.source: MED-V uses Network Address Translation (NAT) to share the host's IP for outgoing traffic.
segment.target: MED-V uses Network Address Translation (NAT) to share the host's IP for outgoing traffic.

segment.source: A general time-out value, in seconds, that MED-V waits for a task to be completed, such as restarting and shutting down.
segment.target: A general time-out value, in seconds, that MED-V waits for a task to be completed, such as restarting and shutting down.

segment.source: This section lists the configurable MED-V guest registry keys and explains their uses.
segment.target: This section lists the configurable MED-V guest registry keys and explains their uses.

segment.source: The following table provides information about the guest registry value associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2 key.
segment.target: The following table provides information about the guest registry value associated with the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftMedvv2 key.

segment.source: Configures how MED-V handles the keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.
segment.target: Configures how MED-V handles the keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.

segment.source: By default, MED-V sets these keys as follows:
segment.target: By default, MED-V sets these keys as follows:

segment.source: Create the EnableGPWorkarounds key, if it is necessary, and set the key to zero if you do not want MED-V to change the default settings of BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.
segment.target: Create the EnableGPWorkarounds key, if it is necessary, and set the key to zero if you do not want MED-V to change the default settings of BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.

segment.source: If your MED-V workspace is running in NAT mode, EnableGPWorkarounds affects the registry keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.
segment.target: If your MED-V workspace is running in NAT mode, EnableGPWorkarounds affects the registry keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.

segment.source: If your MED-V workspace is running in BRIDGED mode, EnableGPWorkarounds only affects the registry key BufferPolicyReads.
segment.target: If your MED-V workspace is running in BRIDGED mode, EnableGPWorkarounds only affects the registry key BufferPolicyReads.

segment.source: 1=true: MED-V sets the keys BufferPolicyReads=1 and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate=0 (if running in NAT mode) or just BufferPolicyReads=1 (if running in BRIDGED mode).
segment.target: 1=true: MED-V sets the keys BufferPolicyReads=1 and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate=0 (if running in NAT mode) or just BufferPolicyReads=1 (if running in BRIDGED mode).

segment.source: 0=false: MED-V does not make any changes to the keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.
segment.target: 0=false: MED-V does not make any changes to the keys BufferPolicyReads and GroupPolicyMinTransferRate.
